image.altText: Santa teresa two ladies and little girl sleeping

items.synopsis: People in the remote community of Ltyentye Apurte are pleading with governments to not forget their struggles, following the result of the Voice referendum.

title.children: In Camilla and Leonie's community, 20 people can sleep in one house. They don't want to be forgotten

image.altText: Mother holds child in front of hospital equipment as child cries

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people are believed to be dead after a blast at a crammed Gaza hospital that Israel and Palestinian militants are blaming on each other, while regional leaders postpone meetings with Joe Biden ahead of his visit to Israel.

title.children: Israel and Palestinian militants blame each other after hospital blast kills hundreds in Gaza

image.altText: Three people move a stretcher with a man on it who is bandaged up.

items.synopsis: The US president directs his national security team to investigate a blast that killed hundreds in Gaza ahead of his visit to Israel. Follow live for the latest updates.

title.children: Biden pledges investigation into Gaza hospital blast as additional repatriation flight for Australians confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra. "We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said. "The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life. "Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian. "Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount. "We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese says 'every innocent life matters'

props.alt: A man giving a press conference in a suit and tie in front of flags

children.content: (ABC News)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister
Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra.
"We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said.
"The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life.
"Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian.

"Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount.
"We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened. "I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement. "The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden expresses outrage over Gaza hospital blast, says US will investigate

children.content: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened.
"I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement.
"The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai. A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians. Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed. Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan. She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government planning another repatriation flight today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai.
A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians.
Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed.
Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan.
She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

image.altText: A close up photo of a man wearing a suit and blue tie.

items.synopsis: Usually in times of war Israelis put aside political differences. This time it's different — support for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has crashed, writes John Lyons.

title.children: While all eyes are on the bigger war with Gaza, small confrontations are erupting all over Israel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some breaking news from the AFL. They're bringing the embargo forward by an hour, maybe because that's how long it will take them to properly detail the brainbuster trade from yesterday afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trades will be processed from 2pm AEDT

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's no ordinary day of trade period. Things work a little differently on deadline day. Representatives from clubs will recommence discussions this morning before they all convene at Docklands Stadium this afternoon No trades can be confirmed or announced until 3pm AEDT A member from each club's list management team will front the media throughout the afternoon The trade period officially ends at 7.30pm AEDT. All paperwork must be lodged with the AFL by that time for a deal to be ratified
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How does deadline day work?

children.content: (Getty Images)
It's no ordinary day of trade period. Things work a little differently on deadline day.
Representatives from clubs will recommence discussions this morning before they all convene at Docklands Stadium this afternoon
No trades can be confirmed or announced until 3pm AEDT
A member from each club's list management team will front the media throughout the afternoon
The trade period officially ends at 7.30pm AEDT.
All paperwork must be lodged with the AFL by that time for a deal to be ratified

items.synopsis: Local shares open slightly higher, after a mixed session on Wall Street. Follow the day's financial news and insights in our live blog.

title.children: Debt collector Credit Corp shares in freefall after dropping 30pc, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wow. Credit Corp Group shares are down a hefty -30% to $12.05 (at 11:15am AEDT). It's all because the debt collector slashed its profit guidance, after a writedown in the valuation of its US debt ledger assets. It will result in a one-off reduction in net profit after tax of $45 million. Here's a chart showing today's fall. Yikes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Credit Corp Group shares in freefall

children.content: Wow.
Credit Corp Group shares are down a hefty -30% to $12.05 (at 11:15am AEDT).
It's all because the debt collector slashed its profit guidance, after a writedown in the valuation of its US debt ledger assets.
It will result in a one-off reduction in net profit after tax of $45 million.
Here's a chart showing today's fall. Yikes.

props.alt: A chart showing a steep fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 400 bank branches across Australia have been closed in the past financial year, according to new figures from the prudential regulator. 122 of those branches were in regional and remote areas. It continues a trend that has seen branch numbers decline by 34% in regional and remote areas, and 37% overall, since the end of June 2017. It comes as a Senate inquiry into bank closures in regional Australia continues, with the next public hearing on December 1.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Has your local bank branch shut?

children.content: More than 400 bank branches across Australia have been closed
in the past financial year, according to new figures from the prudential regulator.
122 of those branches were in regional and remote areas.
It continues a trend that has seen branch numbers decline by 34% in regional and remote areas
, and 37% overall, since the end of June 2017.
It comes as a
Senate inquiry into bank closures in regional Australia continues
, with the next public hearing on December 1.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I've got another acquisition to tell you about! Mirvac Group will buy land lease operator Serenitas, owned by Singapore's sovereign-wealth fund GIC, for $643 million. Serenitas' portfolio comprises 27 "lifestyle communities" for over 50s at more than 6,200 sites across Australia. The purchase will be a joint venture in which Mirvac and Pacific Equity Partners hold about 47.5% each, with the remaining minority interest held by Tasman Capital Partners. Mirvac's Group CEO Campbell Hanan says the acquisition expands its residential offering. "Our expansion into the living sectors comes against a backdrop of critical housing undersupply, and tailwinds including rising population growth, record low vacancy levels and affordability challenges," he said. Mr Hanan says there are an estimated 7.5 million people over 55 years old in Australia in 2023, with strong forecast growth in this population, projected to almost double over the next 40 years. "This transaction immediately scales our exposure to the land lease communities sector across Australia and reinforces our position as the only residential developer in Australia delivering across the spectrum of housing typologies from rental housing, build to rent, land lease, house and land, medium density and high density living. This depth of capability leaves Mirvac well placed to benefit from the structural tailwinds supporting the broader living sector in Australia," he said. Mirvac will fund the transaction from existing liquidity sources and recent asset disposals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Property developer Mirvac's multi-million-dollar purchase

children.content: I've got another acquisition to tell you about!
Mirvac Group will buy land lease operator Serenitas
, owned by Singapore's sovereign-wealth fund GIC,
for $643 million
Serenitas' portfolio comprises
27 "lifestyle communities" for over 50s
at more than
6,200 sites across Australia.
The purchase will be a joint venture in which Mirvac and Pacific Equity Partners hold about 47.5% each, with the remaining minority interest held by Tasman Capital Partners.
Mirvac's Group CEO Campbell Hanan says the acquisition
expands its residential offering

"Our expansion into the living sectors comes against a backdrop of critical housing undersupply, and tailwinds including rising population growth, record low vacancy levels and affordability challenges," he said.
Mr Hanan says there are an estimated 7.5 million people over 55 years old in Australia in 2023, with strong forecast growth in this population, projected to almost double over the next 40 years.

"This transaction immediately scales our exposure to the land lease communities sector across Australia and reinforces our position as the only residential developer in Australia delivering across the spectrum of housing typologies from rental housing, build to rent, land lease, house and land, medium density and high density living.
This depth of capability leaves Mirvac well placed to benefit from the structural tailwinds supporting the broader living sector in Australia," he said.
Mirvac will fund the transaction from existing liquidity sources and recent asset disposals.

image.altText: Older man with grey hair and glasses sits on his porch with a cup of tea in hand

items.synopsis: Indigenous elders and community leaders are reacting to the weekend's No vote with shock, anger and sadness. Some say it'll be too late for them to see change in their lifetime, but are calling on Australia to do better by the next generation of First Nations people.

title.children: 'We thought Australia can't be this bad': Elders grieve Voice referendum result

title.children: They weigh more, use more fuel and may be more dangerous. So why are more Australians driving SUVs?

image.altText: Two fans in Swedish colours react emotionally in the crowd.

image.altText: Two parents hold up a child by each hand as they walk through the woods.

title.children: What is 'good enough parenting'? And could some 'mistakes' actually help children become resilient?

image.altText: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released

image.altText: Owen Farrell gives the thumbs up

items.synopsis: New Zealand and South Africa reached the Rugby World Cup semifinals after brutal wins against the top-two ranked teams in the world. England and Argentina have not had nearly as tough a road on paper, but that will mean nothing come this weekend.

title.children: Rugby World Cup semifinals pits two clear favourites against two teams lucky to be there
